articles.headline: Stanford Fraud Case Puts Old Friends at Odds
articles.snippet: The case could come down to who the jury decides was the mastermind of what prosecutors called an international crime that defrauded nearly 30,000 investors over more than 20 years.
articles.abstract: The case could come down to who the jury decides was the mastermind of what prosecutors called an international crime that defrauded nearly 30,000 investors over more than 20 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — R. Allen Stanford and James M. Davis were roommates at Baylor University and trusted friends over three decades who together built an international financial empire. But this week they are scheduled to confront each other in federal court as indicted swindlers ready to cross swords.

articles.headline: Second Year In, Republican Governors Moderate Tone
articles.snippet: Many who swept into office last year with aggressive plans to cut spending and curb union powers are sounding less confrontational after a backlash from constituents.
articles.abstract: Many who swept into office last year with aggressive plans to cut spending and curb union powers are sounding less confrontational after a backlash from constituents.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after a coterie of new Republican governors swept into the statehouses and put in place aggressive agendas to cut spending and curb union powers, sparking strong backlashes in many places, many of them are adopting decidedly more moderate tones as they begin their sophomore year in office.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Fines a Collector of Debt $2.5 Million
articles.snippet: Asset Acceptance, which buys old debts and tries to collect on them, has settled a Federal Trade Commission case charging that it deceived consumers.
articles.abstract: Asset Acceptance, which buys old debts and tries to collect on them, has settled a Federal Trade Commission case charging that it deceived consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission signaled on Monday that it would continue to crack down on debt collectors who harass consumers for money they may not even be legally obligated to pay.

articles.headline: Treasury Investigates Freddie Mac Investment
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department is investigating whether Freddie Mac bet against refinancings by homeowners while at the same time, making refinancings difficult to obtain.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department is investigating whether Freddie Mac bet against refinancings by homeowners while at the same time, making refinancings difficult to obtain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department is investigating a report that Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant, bet against homeowners’ ability to refinance their loans even as it was making it more difficult for them to do so, Jay Carney, a White House spokesman, said on Monday.

articles.headline: Trade Protest Is Planned on Eve of a Chinese Leader’s Visit
articles.snippet: A coalition of union leaders and trade advocates accuse Beijing of unfairly subsidizing Chinese auto parts makers.
articles.abstract: A coalition of union leaders and trade advocates accuse Beijing of unfairly subsidizing Chinese auto parts makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As the White House prepares for a Washington visit by the man who is expected to run China for the coming decade, trade tensions between the United States and Beijing are on the rise.

articles.headline: Tunisia Faces a Balancing Act of Democracy and Religion
articles.snippet: A blasphemy trial in Tunis symbolizes an emotional struggle, with implications for the Arab world, playing out with the rise of Islamists after the end of a secular dictatorship.
articles.abstract: A blasphemy trial in Tunis symbolizes an emotional struggle, with implications for the Arab world, playing out with the rise of Islamists after the end of a secular dictatorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The insults were furious. “Infidel!” and “Apostate!” the religious protesters shouted at the two men who had come to the courthouse to show their support for a television director on trial on charges of blasphemy. Fists, then a head butt followed.

articles.headline: Buoyant Romney Speaks of Victory in Florida
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is not just playing to win in Florida, but to win as big as possible, aides said, preferably by more than the margin Newt Gingrich had in the South Carolina primary.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is not just playing to win in Florida, but to win as big as possible, aides said, preferably by more than the margin Newt Gingrich had in the South Carolina primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney swept through a final day of campaigning here on Monday, energized by more polls showing him with a commanding lead in the Florida primary. He even allowed himself to break superstition and proclaim, “I’m beginning to feel we might win.”
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: For Soldier Disfigured in War, a Way to Return to the World
articles.snippet: With help from a program that aids badly burned veterans, Joey Paulk received surgery that revived a measure of his self-confidence.
articles.abstract: With help from a program that aids badly burned veterans, Joey Paulk received surgery that revived a measure of his self-confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Specialist Joey Paulk awoke from a coma in a Texas hospital three weeks after he was burned nearly to death in Afghanistan. Wrapped in bandages from head almost to toe, he immediately saw his girlfriend and mother, and felt comforted. Then he glanced at his hands, two balls of white gauze, and realized that he had no fingers.
